I'm happy to report that Galactic Arms Race (GAR), which is built around a =
variant of NEAT called "content-generating NEAT" (cgNEAT), has been selecte=
d as one of 12 finalists in the Indie Game Challenge, out of more than 250 =
submissions:

http://www.indiegamechallenge.com/home/

http://www.indiegame=
challenge.com/finalists/galactic-arms-race/

I know a lot of people on this=
 group are interested in seeing neuroevolution someday appearing in a comme=
rcial game, which is something of course we're hoping to encourage with pro=
jects like GAR.  While much of the industry is skeptical about cutting edge=
 AI technologies, such technologies offer the potential for new kinds of ga=
ming experiences in the future.

Part of the contest is a "Gamer's Choice A=
ward," which allows the general public to vote for a favorite, so you can s=
how your support for neuroevolution in games :)  (Or vote for any of the ot=
her great finalists there that you prefer!)

We've posted two publications =
on GAR:

Journal (including lots of interesting multiplayer server stats): =

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/hastings.ieeetciaig09.html

Conf=
erence:
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/hastings.cig09.html

ken
=
